verses.text: When morning came, all the chief priests and elders of the people took counsel against Jesus to put Him to death.
verses.comment: The collaboration of religious leaders fulfills prophecy about opposition to the Messiah.

verses.text: They bound Him, led Him away, and delivered Him over to Pilate, the governor.
verses.comment: The handing over to Roman authority signals Jesus' innocence under divine law, yet bearing the weight of governmental judgment.

verses.text: Then Judas, who betrayed Him, saw that Jesus had been condemned. He was seized with remorse and returned the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and elders.
verses.comment: Judas' remorse highlights the gravity of betraying the Messiah. The mention of thirty pieces of silver echoes Old Testament prophecy.

verses.text: "I have sinned by betraying innocent blood," he said. But they replied, "What is that to us? See to it yourself."
verses.comment: Judas confesses Jesus' innocence, a critical theological claim that affirms Christ's sinlessness.

verses.text: Throwing down the silver in the temple, he departed and went and hanged himself.
verses.comment: Judas' tragic end fulfills the consequences of grave sin and prophetic warnings about betrayers.

verses.text: But the chief priests took the silver and said, "It is not lawful to put it into the treasury, since it is the price of blood."
verses.comment: Their concern for the law contrasts with their rejection of Christ, demonstrating ritual observance versus true justice.

verses.text: So they took counsel and used the money to buy the potter’s field as a burial place for strangers.
verses.comment: The fulfillment of prophecy is shown in the purchase of the potter’s field.

verses.text: Therefore that field has been called the Field of Blood to this day.
verses.comment: The name’s legacy connects the fate of the betrayer and the consequences of sin.

verses.text: Then was fulfilled what had been spoken through the prophet Jeremiah, "And they took the thirty silver coins, the price of Him who had been valued by the children of Israel,"
verses.comment: Matthew references Jeremiah but the specific wording is closer to Zechariah; this shows shared prophetic expectation.

verses.text: "and they gave them for the potter’s field, as the Lord had directed me."
verses.comment: Demonstrates fulfillment of the pattern of betrayal and redemption foreshadowed by Old Testament prophecy.

verses.text: Now Jesus stood before the governor. The governor asked Him, "Are you the King of the Jews?" Jesus answered, "You say so."
verses.comment: Jesus' response points to His true kingship, associating divinity and fulfillment of Messiah prophecy.

verses.text: But when He was accused by the chief priests and elders, He gave no answer.
verses.comment: Jesus' silence fulfills prophecy regarding the suffering servant; His humility is exemplary for believers.

verses.text: Then Pilate said to Him, "Do You not hear how many things they are testifying against You?"
verses.comment: Pilate’s bewilderment contrasts human judgment with Christ’s divine forbearance.

verses.text: But He did not answer him even to a single charge, so that the governor was greatly amazed.
verses.comment: His peaceful silence testifies to a higher purpose and an inner authority that surpasses earthly power.

verses.text: Now at the feast the governor was accustomed to release to the crowd one prisoner whom they wanted.
verses.comment: The custom of releasing a prisoner emphasizes the contrast between Christ, the innocent one, and the guilty.

verses.text: And they had then a notorious prisoner called Barabbas.
verses.comment: Barabbas’ notoriety sets the stage for the substitution of the innocent for the guilty, echoing the core of atonement.

verses.text: So when they were gathered, Pilate said to them, "Whom do you want me to release for you: Barabbas, or Jesus who is called the Christ?"
verses.comment: The identification of Jesus as 'the Christ' clarifies His messianic identity to the crowd.

verses.text: For he knew that it was out of envy that they had delivered Him up.
verses.comment: Pilate recognizes the motive; envy is a recurring theme in sinful rejection of divine truth.

verses.text: While he was sitting on the judgment seat, his wife sent word to him, saying, "Have nothing to do with that righteous man, for I have suffered much because of Him today in a dream."
verses.comment: Divine intervention through dreams signifies Christ’s holiness and innocence.

verses.text: But the chief priests and the elders persuaded the crowds to ask for Barabbas and destroy Jesus.
verses.comment: The leaders’ manipulation of the crowd shows the depth of opposition to Jesus’ saving mission.

verses.text: The governor again said to them, "Which of the two do you want me to release to you?" They said, "Barabbas."
verses.comment: The crowd’s choice is a stark symbol of humanity’s need for redemption through Christ.

verses.text: Pilate said to them, "Then what shall I do with Jesus who is called the Christ?" They all said, "Let Him be crucified!"
verses.comment: Crucifixion was reserved for the most shameful criminals; Christ’s death thus bears the curse (Deut. 21:23).

verses.text: And he said, "Why? What evil has He done?" But they shouted all the more, "Let Him be crucified!"
verses.comment: Pilate’s question reiterates Christ’s innocence, the crowd’s demand fulfills Isaiah’s prophecy about the suffering servant.

verses.text: When Pilate saw that he was gaining nothing, but rather that a riot was beginning, he took water and washed his hands before the crowd, saying, "I am innocent of this man’s blood; see to it yourselves."
verses.comment: Pilate’s symbolic act reflects Old Testament ritual, though responsibility remains—a nuanced view of leadership and moral accountability.

verses.text: And all the people answered, "His blood be on us and on our children!"
verses.comment: This utterance reflects the seriousness of rejecting the Savior, yet anticipates future mercy offered to all people.

verses.text: Then he released Barabbas to them, but after having Jesus scourged, he delivered Him to be crucified.
verses.comment: The scourging fulfilled prophecy of physical suffering (Isa. 53:5) and prefigures redemptive suffering.

verses.text: Then the soldiers of the governor took Jesus into the governor's headquarters and gathered the whole battalion before Him.
verses.comment: This public mockery was meant to shame, yet reveals the depths of Christ’s humility.

verses.text: And they stripped Him and put a scarlet robe on Him.
verses.comment: The scarlet robe symbolizes mockery of kingship but foreshadows Christ’s true royal dignity.

verses.text: And twisting together a crown of thorns, they put it on His head and placed a reed in His right hand. Then kneeling before Him, they mocked Him, saying, "Hail, King of the Jews!"
verses.comment: Crown of thorns signifies suffering and kingship, uniting Christ’s priestly and kingly offices.

verses.text: And they spat on Him and took the reed and struck Him on the head.
verses.comment: Christ’s patient suffering under humiliation epitomizes the highest virtue.

verses.text: And when they had mocked Him, they took off the robe and put His own clothes on Him, and led Him away to crucify Him.
verses.comment: Jesus' willingness to submit shows the depth of His self-sacrifice for mankind.

verses.text: As they went out, they found a man of Cyrene, Simon by name; they compelled this man to carry His cross.
verses.comment: Simon’s participation hints at joining in Christ’s suffering, a theme central to the Christian life.

verses.text: And when they came to a place called Golgotha (which means Place of a Skull),
verses.comment: Golgotha becomes the focal point of redemption and sacrifice.

verses.text: they offered Him wine mixed with gall to drink, but when He tasted it, He would not drink it.
verses.comment: Rejecting the stupefying drink, Jesus chooses to endure the fullness of His suffering.

verses.text: When they had crucified Him, they divided His garments among them, casting lots.
verses.comment: The casting of lots for His clothing is a cited fulfillment of messianic prophecy.

verses.text: Then they sat down and kept watch over Him there.
verses.comment: The guards’ actions ensure that the execution was public and official, leaving no dispute about its occurrence.

verses.text: And over His head they put the written charge against Him, "This is Jesus, the King of the Jews."
verses.comment: The title proclaims Christ's kingship, ironically displayed even in death; hints at His unique universal reign.

verses.text: Then two robbers were crucified with Him, one on the right and one on the left.
verses.comment: His association with criminals fulfills prophecy and illustrates His solidarity with sinners.

verses.text: Those who passed by hurled insults at Him, shaking their heads.
verses.comment: The mockery fulfills messianic prophecy and shows the depth of human rejection.

verses.text: And saying, "You who would destroy the temple and rebuild it in three days, save Yourself! If You are the Son of God, come down from the cross!"
verses.comment: Their demand is a denial of Christ’s divine mission; the ‘Son of God’ title affirms His divine identity under trial.

verses.text: So also the chief priests, the scribes, and elders mocked Him, saying,
verses.comment: Even religious leaders participate in scoffing, further fulfilling prophecies of rejection.

verses.text: "He saved others; He cannot save Himself. He is the King of Israel; let Him come down now from the cross, and we will believe in Him."
verses.comment: True kingship is shown in sacrificial love, not self-preservation—a central aspect of Christ's redemptive act.

verses.text: "He trusts in God; let God deliver Him now, if He delights in Him—for He said, 'I am the Son of God.'"
verses.comment: Their words echo Psalm 22 and further demonstrate the fulfillment of the suffering servant motif and claims of Jesus' divinity.

verses.text: Even the robbers who were crucified with Him heaped insults on Him.
verses.comment: Participation in mockery from all sides deepens Christ’s rejection and suffering.

verses.text: Now from the sixth hour until the ninth hour there was darkness over all the land.
verses.comment: The supernatural darkness indicates divine judgment and cosmic sorrow over Jesus’ suffering.

verses.text: And about the ninth hour Jesus cried out with a loud voice, saying, "Eli, Eli, lema sabachthani?" that is, "My God, My God, why have You forsaken Me?"
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Psalm 22, expressing the depths of His suffering, yet pointing to fulfillment of prophecy and ultimate trust.

verses.text: Some of those standing there, hearing it, said, "This man is calling Elijah."
verses.comment: The crowd misinterprets Jesus’ words, looking for Elijah as a messianic deliverer.

verses.text: One of them ran and took a sponge, filled it with sour wine, put it on a stick, and gave Him to drink.
verses.comment: The sour wine echoes prophetic suffering noted in the Psalms.

verses.text: But the rest said, "Wait, let us see whether Elijah will come to save Him."
verses.comment: A continued misunderstanding of the true nature of Jesus’ mission and Messiahship.

verses.text: And Jesus cried out again with a loud voice and gave up His spirit.
verses.comment: Jesus’ voluntary surrender of His spirit demonstrates His full authority, a claim to divine prerogative.

verses.text: And behold, the veil of the temple was torn in two, from top to bottom; and the earth shook, and rocks were split.
verses.comment: The torn veil signifies open access to God through Jesus; the quake shows cosmic significance of His death.

verses.text: The tombs also were opened, and many bodies of saints who had fallen asleep were raised,
verses.comment: The resurrection of these holy ones foreshadows the general resurrection and Christ’s victory over death.

verses.text: and coming out of the tombs after His resurrection, they went into the holy city and appeared to many.
verses.comment: Their appearance affirms the power of Christ’s resurrection, confirming its historic and spiritual reality.

verses.text: When the centurion and those who were with him, keeping watch over Jesus, saw the earthquake and what took place, they were filled with awe and said, "Truly this was the Son of God!"
verses.comment: Gentile confession of Christ’s divinity points to universal significance—a bridge between old and new covenants.

verses.text: There were also many women there, looking on from a distance, who had followed Jesus from Galilee, ministering to Him.
verses.comment: The faithful women model discipleship and loyalty even in trial, signifying the redemptive role given to all believers.

verses.text: Among them were Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of the sons of Zebedee.
verses.comment: Mention of specific names of witnesses underlines the reliability of the account and the prominent role of women in the early church.

verses.text: When it was evening, there came a rich man from Arimathea, named Joseph, who also was a disciple of Jesus.
verses.comment: Joseph’s role highlights the dignity and courage required to honor the Lord in His death.

verses.text: He went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus. Then Pilate ordered it to be given to him.
verses.comment: The permission for burial fulfills prophecy and the requirement to honor the body.

verses.text: Joseph took the body, wrapped it in a clean linen shroud,
verses.comment: The care for Jesus’ body signifies reverence and preparation for resurrection.

verses.text: and placed it in his own new tomb, which he had cut in the rock. He rolled a large stone across the entrance and departed.
verses.comment: Christ’s burial in a rich man’s tomb fulfills Isaiah's prophecy and highlights the dignity reserved for Him.

verses.text: Mary Magdalene and the other Mary were there, sitting opposite the tomb.
verses.comment: Continuous witness by the women underlines continuity and care—an important historic and spiritual affirmation.

verses.text: The next day, that is, after the day of preparation, the chief priests and the Pharisees gathered before Pilate
verses.comment: Their continued vigilance against Jesus hints at divine protection and the certainty of His resurrection.

verses.text: and said, "Sir, we remember how that deceiver said, while He was still alive, ‘After three days I will rise.'"
verses.comment: They unwittingly reaffirm Christ’s prophetic claims, remembering His prediction about resurrection.

verses.text: "Therefore command the tomb to be made secure until the third day, lest His disciples come and steal Him away and tell the people, ‘He has risen from the dead,’ and the last deception will be worse than the first."
verses.comment: Their efforts to secure the tomb ironically strengthen the evidence for the reality of the resurrection.

verses.text: Pilate said to them, "You have a guard of soldiers. Go, make it as secure as you can."
verses.comment: Pilate gives permission, further ensuring that no natural explanation can undermine the glory of the resurrection.

verses.text: So they went and made the tomb secure by sealing the stone and setting a guard.
verses.comment: The seal and guard provide proof that His resurrection will be of divine, not human, origin, elevating the miraculous truth of the event for all believers.
